stretched_canvas_reviews.review_title: What a great way to recycle!
stretched_canvas_reviews.review_desc: I am shocked by this canvas. It feels and acts just like fabric but it's recycled bottles! It came pre-primed. The paint adheres well. I really like the overall value and outcome of the painting. I'll definitely be buying this canvas and other recycled material based supplies in the future.

The Liquitex recycled canvas is a great product and I will be purchasing this canvas over the non recycled canvas from now on. The canvas itself is high quality and it produces quality paintings. The paint glides on very smoothly and feels just like a regular cotton canvas.

stretched_canvas_reviews.review_title: Helping the planet one artwork at a time
stretched_canvas_reviews.review_desc: I wasn't expecting the Liquitex Recycled Canvas to be as high quality as it was. I love that it's made from recycled bottles and FSC certified wood, and even the label is recycled content and all packaging is fully recyclable ! It comes already primed which made it easy to get started. It's a bit heavier weight cloth than regular canvas, but I actually liked that better, since I am using a mix of regular acrylic, heavy body acrylic, and some other media on this piece. Unfortunately due to a health issue I have not been able to work on the piece much to show any photos ( it is also going to be a surprise gift). Liquitex has made a great product, one that I will be using exclusively from now on. You can feel good that you're going to create great artwork and also do your bit to help get plastic out of the ecosystem.
This canvas was such amazing quality! It was sturdy and had a little bit of weight to it which I personally prefer. You can definitely tell how well this was made and I'm going to be buying more!

I'm not a huge fan of Winsor & Newton, especially since they've been bought out by the ColArt Group. But I have to admit, their stretched cotton canvas is the best you can get. If you want better quality than this, you'll be stretching your own. My biggest problem with pre-stretched canvas has always been canvas tightness. I like my canvas nice and tight. I don't want it wiggling around while I'm trying to paint. This canvas is relatively tight right out of the package. And it comes with these cool adjustable wedges. These wedges take it to the next level. So if you work on cotton canvas, and you prefer to buy pre-stretched, I highly recommend that you give this product a try.

However, fine linens often have an open weave where light can shine through the priming. In addition, in fine weaves it's not unusual for the priming to penetrate and show white spots on the back of the fabric, but since the canvas has been sized (and the sizing is clear), there is no harm to the linen fibers. Both characteristics are sometimes mistaken for pinholes, but they are not holes and not flaws. Nonetheless, we welcome you to return any item that does not meet your expectations. alcohol_markers_reviews.product: Prismacolor Premier Dual-Ended Chisel Tip Markers and Sets
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_desc: Well, you can't say that they don't hold up. I purchased my one and only set waaaay back in 1985 from our local Dick Blick (closed over 20 years ago) while attending college. Anyway, a few years back I suffered a stroke which somewhat curtailed my model hobby that started again after I retired. So these past four years I got back into coloring books. Not all the time mind you but just to break the boredom. Then this past month I purchased some adult based coloring books for markers, and that got me to thinking about these markers I had down in my studio cabinet. Lo and behold, they are still quite functional, but I have a few that after reopening the caps, they start to dry out until I put the cap back on and let it rest for a day or two. I think a new set is in the future. Yet, after almost 40 years, I can't complain about a very good purchase.

alcohol_markers_reviews.review_desc: They are good alcohol markers however the smell is stronger than every other alcohol marker I have (Ohuhu, Copic, Arrtyx, Grabie). They give me a headache. The other brands I did not really notice an issue with the smell being too strong. Especially Ohuhu they win in the least smell category for me. If you have a sensitive nose I would not recommend the Olo's. Especially at how much they cost.

alcohol_markers_reviews.product: Olo Dual-Tip Markers and Sets
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_desc: I wasn't looking for markers, but they were on clearance near the checkouts and I impulsively bought the "autumn" pack. The light colors are nice and soft for building layers. The bullet nibs seem like great quality and hold their shape. I didn't notice any bleeding, I didn't really attempt to blend so cannot speak to that. I didn't know when I bought them that they had replacement cartridges, it's a great idea. Even just the ability to custom build a palette and save some space for on the go is great. I'm going back to buy out whatever other colors I can find if there are any left!

alcohol_markers_reviews.product: Olo Dual-Tip Markers and Sets
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_title: Try a small set. See how you like it. You might be surprised
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_desc: I have to say, these are a great alternative to the more expensive professional marker brand. Comparing the orange Olo to the orange Copic, there was virtually no difference in color. The other thing is that they don't have the heavy alcohol smell that Copics have. The dual tip connection feature is a great idea as well as being able to order handles, connectors and fills. I would highly recommend people purchase at least a small set to get an idea of what they can do. I give it 4 stars because blending wet over wet didn't seem to do anything on various papers.

alcohol_markers_reviews.product: Sakura Identi-Pen Dual-Point Marking Pen
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_title: Good product, but don't wet the nib!
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_desc: Good product, but won't really mark on everything! It does not seem to want to write after nib gets wet or even damp. Especially the super-fine end. Ink is darkly pigmented and permanent once dry, dries quickly, and marks great on paper, wood, glass, canvas, vinyl, Ziplock bags, shiny plastic, dull or matte plastic, metal, fabric, and cured polymer clay. I've found that when used on non-porous surfaces, you can remove it using alcohol. Be sure to put the caps on tightly, or these markers dry-out very quickly!
